Before sending your Cloudflare log data to Splunk, ensure that you:
Have an existing Splunk Enterprise or Cloud account
Task 1 - Install and Configure the Cloudflare App for Splunk
Log in to your Splunk instance.
Restart and reopen your Splunk instance.
source type in the Cloudflare App for Splunk. To edit the source type:
and change the Regex expression to
Create an index on Splunk to store the HTTP Event logs. To create an index:
Open the setup screen by clicking the
page also gives you the status of all your existing indexes so that you can see whether you're about to use up your licensed amount of space.
, which is the default index that the Cloudflare App will use.
Set up the HTTP Event Collector (HEC) on Splunk. To create an HEC:
and follow the wizard. When prompted, submit the following responses:
App Context: Cloudflare App for Splunk (cloudflare)
At the end of the wizard you will see a
. This token authorizes the Cloudflare Logpush job to send data to your Splunk instance. If you forget to copy it now, Splunk allows you to get the value at any time.
Verify whether Splunk is using a self-signed certificate. You'll need this information when creating the Logpush job.
Determine the endpoint to use to send the data to. The endpoint should be:
based on whether you have a self-service or managed cloud plan
: The hostname of your Splunk instance. The easiest way to determine the hostname is to look at the URL you went to when you logged in to Splunk.
after initial configuration by accessing the app
You also can find the Index Name manually by visiting
The Cloudflare App for Splunk comes with a custom Cloudflare Data Model that has an acceleration time frame of 1 day but is not accelerated by default. If you enable
, we recommend that the Data Model is only accelerated for 1 or 7 days to ensure there are no adverse effects within your Splunk environment.
Enable or disable acceleration after the initial configuration by accessing the app Set up page by clicking the
You can also manually configure Data Models by going to
. Learn more about data model acceleration in the
Task 2 - Make the API call to create the Logpush job
Create the Logpush job by following the instructions on
. The API call creates a Logpush job but does not enable it.
Enable the Logpush job through the the Cloudflare dashboard or through the API by following the instructions on
Navigate to the Cloudflare dashboard and select
and select the fields referenced in the Dashboard section below to fully populate all tables and graphs.
Enable the Logpush job by toggling on the switch next to the Edit link. Data takes a few minutes to populate.
To validate that you are receiving data, search
You can analyze Cloudflare logs with the thirteen (13) dashboards listed below.
You can use filters within these dashboards to help narrow the analysis by date and time, device type, country, user agent, client IP, hostname, and more to further help with debugging and tracing.
The following dashboards outlined below are available as part of the Cloudflare App for Splunk.
: Get an overview of the most important metrics from your websites and applications on the Cloudflare network.

: Get insights on the availability of your websites and applications. Metrics include origin response error ratio, origin response status over time, percentage of 3xx/4xx/5xx errors over time, and more.
: Get insights on threats to your websites and applications, including number of threats stopped, threats over time, top threat countries, and more.

: Get insights on threat identification and mitigation by our Web Application Firewall, including events like SQL injections, XSS, and more. Use this data to fine tune the firewall to target obvious threats and prevent false positives.
: Get insights on rate limiting protection against denial-of-service attacks, brute-force login attempts, and other types of abusive behavior targeted at your websites or applications.

children.alt: Splunk dashboard Cloudflare Security Rate Limiting

children.value: : Investigate bot activity on your website to prevent content scraping, checkout fraud, spam registration and other malicious activities.

children.alt: Splunk dashboard Cloudflare Security Bots Summary
Splunk dashboard Cloudflare Security Bots Detailed

children.value: : Identify and address performance issues and caching misconfigurations. Metrics include total vs. cached bandwidth, saved bandwidth, total requests, cache ratio, top uncached requests, and more.

children.alt: Splunk dashboard Cloudflare Performance Requests and Cache

children.value: Hostname, Content Type, Request Methods, Connection Type
: Get insights into your most popular hostnames, most requested content types, breakdown of request methods, and connection type.

children.alt: Splunk dashboard Cloudflare Performance Hostname, Content Type, Request Methods, Connection Type

children.value: : Get insights into the performance of your static and dynamic content, including slowest URLs.

children.alt: Splunk dashboard Cloudflare Performance Static vs. Dynamic Content

children.value: All dashboard have a set of filters that you can apply to the entire dashboard, as shown in the following example. Filters are applied across the entire dashboard.

You can use filters to drill down and examine the data at a granular level. Filters include client country, client device type, client IP, client request host, client request URI, client request user agent, edge response status, origin IP, and origin response status.
The default time interval is set to 24 hours. Note that for correct calculations filter will need to exclude Worker subrequests (
The Splunk Cloudflare App relies on data from the Cloudflare Enterprise Logs fields outlined below. Depending on which fields you have enabled, certain dashboards might not populate fully.

If that is the case, verify and test the Cloudflare App filters below each dashboard (these filters are the same across all dashboards). You can delete any filters that you dont need, even if such filters include data fields already contained in your logs.
Also, you could compare the list of fields you are getting in Cloudflare Logs with the fields listed in
